interestingcomments.content: Glue the edges down so the damage doesn't spread, I don't think there is enough wrong with the rest of the vulcanite to justify a complete recovering. There are things you can do to restore the finish and fill the gaps.

interestingcomments.content: My pet hate is when people describe things like a lens rendition as "Organic". As far as I am concerned, this adjective only applies to chemical compounds containing carbon or vegetables/fruit/grain grown with poo but without insecticide. Wilson
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: My pet hate is when people describe things like a lens rendition as "Organic". As far as I am concerned, this adjective only applies to chemical compounds containing carbon or vegetables/fruit/grain grown with poo but without insecticide. Wilson

interestingcomments.content: Added later - the above photo is also a demonstration of why anyone working on something like a Leica camera MUST have the proper tools. Regular, ordinary screwdrivers are NOT suitable for machine screws. Most people don't seem to realize this, and butcher up screws on whatever they are working on. Yuck. The same thing happens with gunsmiths. They have the proper tools for the job. Customers don't, and bring in their guns with the screw heads all butchered up like what I see above. Sorry for the interruption - I couldn't help it. Things like this really annoy me.
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: Added later - the above photo is also a demonstration of why anyone working on something like a Leica camera MUST have the proper tools. interestingcomments.content: 12 minutes ago, dkmoore said: When printing I never adjust size regardless of paper size. Maybe that is an error unless between LR and the Epson P900 does it for me? Nor do I... I've assumed, and the results seem to indicate, that PS and the P900 handle things related to scaling dots without any need for me to intervene and screw things up. Perhaps those more expert in printing do things differently.

interestingcomments.content: When seen as a problem it's very much a millennial problem, never used a stick shift, never made anything mechanical as a kid, no concept of gears and levers, and even the simplest thing is sent out for repair or abandoned. But I suppose it makes room in the brain for things I find difficult to comprehend, like the list of options in a coffee shop 😉

interestingcomments.content: My CL died in mid August, I sent it to Leica NJ US, the diagnosis was a failed circuit board and a out of adjustment sensor. I tried to get an idea of what caused this, even speculation would be better than nothing. Stacey McHenry Manager of Customer Care from Leica responded "I apologize, the technician is not able to determine what caused the problem, just that the circuit failed." I was kind of hoping it was some thing I had done, or something I could avoid. Guess asking a Leica tech for speculation isn't a thing.

interestingcomments.content: ^ ^ The critical thing for me is whether you need the Adobe software to be compatible with what other people are using. As far as I'm concerned in trying to produce a photobook Indesign is, in that you can send an "Indesign package" to a printshop or a lithographer and they can go straight to their imposition software. Otherwise, one could use alternatives to PS and LR. _______________________Frog Leaping photobook
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: ^ ^ The critical thing for me is whether you need the Adobe software to be compatible with what other people are using. interestingcomments.content: Those fakes, even when declared as such, bothers me. I always report them, but it probably doesn't help. The object is designed to deceive someone and therefore they support a counterfeit culture. Not that I can't laugh at some of the things that comes up, but they were not made for laughing but to dishonestly adding value to an object of lesser value.
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: Those fakes, even when declared as such, bothers me. I always report them, but it probably doesn't help. interestingcomments.content: I think that anecdotal evidence about how the cameras of Tom, Dick and Harry all survived XYZ is reassuring. Of course cameras are like people... some folks have fallen from airplanes without a parachute and survived to tell the tale, while others have been killed by errant golf balls... and just like this sometimes equipment seems indestructible and other times shockingly fragile. There's always some degree of risk... But for my opinion it boils down to what happens if some thing goes wrong.... Personally one thing that worries about my M9 is what repair or replacement options might be available in the event of a disaster..
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: I think that anecdotal evidence about how the cameras of Tom, Dick and Harry all survived XYZ is reassuring. Of course cameras are like people... some folks have fallen from airplanes without a parachute and survived to tell the tale, while others have been killed by errant golf balls... and just like this sometimes equipment seems indestructible and other times shockingly fragile. There's always some degree of risk... But for my opinion it boils down to what happens if some thing goes wrong.... Personally one thing that worries about my M9 is what repair or replacement options might be available in the event of a disaster..
